狼与小羊羔: 狼遇到一只迷途的小羊羔，他决定不用粗暴的手段，而是通过找到某个由头来证明狼吃羊是天经地义的。于是，他对小羊羔说：“小子，你去年粗鲁地辱骂过我。”“可是，”小羊羔伤心地咩咩叫道，“我那时还没出生呢。”然后狼说：“你吃了我牧场里的草。”“不可能啊，我的好先生，”小羊羔答道，“我还没尝过草的味道呢。”狼又说：“你喝了我井里的水。”“不可能，”小羊羔大声喊道，“我还没喝过水呢，因为我还一直在靠喝妈妈的乳汁充饥解渴呢。”这时，狼一把抓住小羊羔，把他吞了下去。狼说：“好吧！就算你驳倒了我所有的借口，我总不能不吃晚饭吧。”暴君总会为他的暴政找到说辞。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Wolf, meeting with a Lamb astray from the fold, resolved not to lay violent hands on him, but to find some plea to justify to the Lamb the Wolf’s right to eat him.He thus addressed him: “Sirrah, last year you grossly insulted me.”“Indeed,” bleated  the Lamb in a  mournful tone of voice, “I was not then born.”Then said the Wolf, “You feed in my pasture.”“No, good sir,” replied the Lamb, “I have not yet tasted grass.”Again said the Wolf, “You drink of my well.”  “No,” exclaimed the Lamb, “I never yet drank water, for as yet my mother’s milk is both food and drink to me.”Upon which the Wolf seized him and ate him up, saying, “Well!I won’t remain supperless, even though you refute every one of my imputations.”The tyrant will always find a pretext for his tyranny.

狼与小羊羔: 蝙蝠与黄鼠狼
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Bat and the Weasels

狼与小羊羔: 一只蝙蝠落到地上，被一只黄鼠狼捉住了，蝙蝠请求黄鼠狼饶他一命。黄鼠狼不答应，说自己生来就是所有鸟类的天敌。蝙蝠极力向黄鼠狼证明自己不是鸟类，而是一只老鼠，并因此获得了自由。不久，这只蝙蝠又一次掉到了地上，被另一只黄鼠狼捉住了。蝙蝠故技重施，请求黄鼠狼不要吃他。这只黄鼠狼说他特别仇恨老鼠。蝙蝠便极力向这只黄鼠狼证明自己不是老鼠，而是一只蝙蝠。就这样，蝙蝠又一次逃脱了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A bat who fell upon the ground and was caught by a Weasel pleaded to be spared his life.The Weasel refused, saying that he was by nature the enemy of all birds.The Bat assured him that he was not a bird, but a mouse, and thus was set free.Shortly afterwards the Bat again fell to the ground and was caught by another Weasel, whom he likewise entreated not to eat him.The Weasel said that he had a special hostility to mice.The Bat assured him that he was not a  mouse, but a bat, and thus a second time escaped.

狼与小羊羔: 懂得随机应变是明智之举。
The Wolf and the Lamb: It is wise to turn circumstances to good account.

狼与小羊羔: 驴子和蚱蜢
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Ass and the Grasshopper

狼与小羊羔: 一头驴子听到几只蚱蜢在唧唧叫，于是被深深迷住了。驴子渴望能享有这同样美妙的旋律，就问蚱蜢们吃的什么食物，竟能发出如此动听的声音。蚱蜢们回答道：“露水。”于是，驴子下决心只以露水为食。没过多久，驴子就饿死了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: An ass having heard some Grasshoppers chirping, was highly  enchanted; and, desiring to possess the same charms of melody,  demanded what sort of food they lived on to give them such beautiful  voices.They replied, “The dew.”The Ass resolved that he would live only upon dew, and in a short time died of hunger.

狼与小羊羔: 狮子和老鼠
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Lion and the Mouse

狼与小羊羔: 一头狮子睡觉时，被一只从他脸上跑过的老鼠给闹醒了。狮子很生气地爬起来，抓住了老鼠，准备杀了他。老鼠连忙可怜地哀求狮子：“如果你放了我，我将来肯定会报答你的。”狮子听了哈哈大笑，放了他。不久，狮子被好几个猎人抓住了，在地上被结结实实地用绳子绑了起来。那只老鼠听出了这头狮子的咆哮声，就跑来用牙齿咬断了绳子，让狮子重获了自由。老鼠高声说道：
The Wolf and the Lamb: A lion was awakened from sleep by a Mouse running over his face.Rising up angrily, he caught him and was about to kill him, when the Mouse piteously entreated, saying: “If you would only spare  my life,  I would be sure to repay your kindness.”The Lion laughed and let him go.It happened shortly after this that the Lion was caught by some  hunters, who bound him by stropes to the ground.The Mouse, recognizing his roar, came gnawed the rope  with his teeth, and set him free, exclaimed:

狼与小羊羔: “上次你嘲笑我，认为我帮不了你，不指望我的回报；现在你明白了吧，即便是一只老鼠，也是可能帮助一头狮子的。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: “You ridiculed the idea of my ever being able to help you, expecting to receive from me any repayment of your favor; now you know that it is possible for even a Mouse to con benefits on a Lion.”

狼与小羊羔: 烧炭工和漂洗工
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Charcoal-Burner and the Fuller

狼与小羊羔: 一位烧炭工在自己的房子里烧炭卖。一天，他遇到一个朋友——一位漂洗工。于是，他恳请这位朋友搬来和他一起住。他说他们要是成为邻居就太好了，这样可以节省很多家用开支。漂洗工答道：“就我个人来说，这种安排是不可能的，因为所有我要漂白的东西，很快就会被你的木炭染黑。”同声相应，同气相求。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Charcoal-Burner carried on his trade in his own house.One day he met a friend, a Fuller, and entreated him to come and live with him, saying that they should be far better neighbors and that their housekeeping expenses would be lessened.The Fuller replied, “The arrangement is impossible as far as I am concerned, for whatever I should whiten, you would immediately blacken again with your charcoal.”Like will draw like.

狼与小羊羔: 父亲和他的儿子们
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Father and His Sons

狼与小羊羔: 有一位父亲，他有几个总是争吵不休的儿子。父亲通过劝诫无法平息儿子们的争执，于是他决心用实例向他们证明不和的坏处。一天，父亲为此让儿子们给他拿一捆柴来。儿子们把柴拿来了，父亲把那捆柴依次放在每个儿子的手中，命他们将这捆柴折断。儿子们使尽力气也折不断这捆柴。接着，父亲散开这捆柴，把枝条一根根取出，又挨个放在儿子们的手上。这一回，他们轻轻松松就把这些枝条给折断了。然后，父亲对儿子们说了这样一番话：“孩子们，如果你们齐心协力、团结互助，在敌人面前就会像这捆柴一样坚不可摧；但如果你们内部不和，就会像这些单根的枝条一样不堪一击。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A father had a family of sons who were perpetually quarreling among themselves.When he failed to heal their disputes by his exhortations, he determined to give them a practical illustration of the evils of disunion; and for this purpose he one day told them to bring him a bundle of sticks.When they had done so, he placed the faggot into the hands of each of them in succession, and ordered them to break it in pieces.They tried with all their strength, and were not able to do it.He next opened the faggot, took the sticks separately, one by one, and again put them into his sons’ hands, upon  which they broke them easily.He then addressed them in these words:  “My sons, if you are of one  mind, and unite to assist each other, you  will be as this faggot, uninjured by all the attempts of your enemies; but if you are divided among yourselves, you will be broken as easily as these sticks.”

狼与小羊羔: 捉蝗虫的男孩
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Boy Hunting Locusts

狼与小羊羔: 一个男孩在捉蝗虫。他已经捉到了很多蝗虫。这时，他看到了一只蝎子，但误以为它是蝗虫，就伸手要去抓它。蝎子亮出它的毒刺，说道：“朋友，一旦你碰了我，你将会失去我，以及你捉到的所有蝗虫！”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A boy was hunting for locusts.He had caught a goodly number, when he saw a Scorpion, and mistaking him for a locust, reached out his hand to take him.The Scorpion, showing his sting, said: “If you had but touched me, my friend, you would have lost me, and all your locusts too!”

狼与小羊羔: 公鸡和珠宝
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Cock and the Jewel

狼与小羊羔: 一只公鸡正在刨地，为自己和它的母鸡们觅食。突然它发现了一块宝石，便大声说道：“如果是你的主人而不是我找到你，他一定会把你奉为至宝，可发现你对我却毫无用处。我宁愿要一粒大麦，也不愿要全世界的珠宝。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Cock, scratching for food for himself and his hens, found a precious stone and exclaimed:  “If your owner had found thee, and not I, he would have taken thee up, and have set thee in thy first estate; but I have found thee for no purpose.I would rather have one barleycorn than all the jewels in the world.”

狼与小羊羔: 狮子的王国
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Kingdom of the Lion

狼与小羊羔: 草原和森林里的野兽们让一头狮子做他们的国王。他既不暴躁残忍，也不蛮横专制，而是拥有一位国王应有的公正和仁慈。在这头狮子的统治期间,他在一次鸟兽全体出席的联合大会上发表了皇家宣言，并为一个集体同盟会草拟了各项条款。其中规定：狼和羊、美洲豹和小山羊、老虎和牡鹿、狗和野兔都应非常友好、和睦地共处。一只野兔说：“哦，我多么期盼能有这么一天啊：弱小的动物与强大的动物在一起，能安然无恙地占有自己的一席之地。”野兔说完后，便跑开去找他的妻子了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The beasts of the field and forest had a Lion as their king.He was neither wrathful, cruel, nor tyrannical, but just and gentle as a king could be.During his reign he made a royal proclamation for a general assembly of all the birds and beasts, and drew up conditions for a universal league, in which the Wolf and the Lamb, the Panther and the Kid, the Tiger and the Stag, the Dog and the Hare, should live together in perfect peace and amity.The Hare said, “Oh, how I have longed to see this day, in which the weak shall take their place with impunity by the side of the strong.”And after the Hare said this, he ran for his wife.

狼与小羊羔: 狼与鹤
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Wolf and the Crane

狼与小羊羔: 一只狼，喉咙里卡了根骨头，于是他出高价雇了一只鹤，要她将头伸进他的嘴里，以取出骨头。鹤取出骨头后，便向狼索要之前答应给她的报酬。狼磨了磨牙，大声说道：“哎呀，我允许你把头安全地从一只狼嘴里拿出来，就已经是对你最大的补偿了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A wolf who had a bone stuck in his throat hired a Crane, for a large sum, to put her head into his mouth and draw out the bone.When the Crane had extracted the bone and demanded the promised  payment, the Wolf, grinning and grinding his teeth, exclaimed: “Why, you have surely already had a sufficient recompense, in having been permitted to draw out your head in safety from the mouth and jaws of a wolf.”

狼与小羊羔: 为邪恶之徒服务，就不能奢望会有回报。要是你的辛苦能让你免于受伤，你就该谢天谢地了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: In serving the wicked, expect no reward, and be thankful if you escape injury for your pains.

狼与小羊羔: 吹笛子的渔夫
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Fisherman Piping

狼与小羊羔: 一个精通音乐的渔夫，带着他的笛子和渔网来到了海边。他站在一块突出的岩石上，吹了几支曲子，希望鱼能被他吹的旋律所吸引，自愿跳进他挂在岩石下面的网里。结果，他等了好久都一无所获，于是他只好把笛子放在一边，把网撒进海里，结果捕到了满满一网鱼。看着网里的鱼在岩石上活蹦乱跳，他说道：“噢，你们这些不识好歹的东西，我给你们吹笛子的时候你们不跳，现在我不吹，你们倒跳得欢了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A fisherman skilled in music took his flute and his nets to the seashore.Standing on a projecting rock, he played several tunes in the hope that the fish, attracted by his melody, would of their own accord dance into his net, which he had placed below.At last, having long waited in vain, he laid aside his flute, and casting his net into the sea, made an excellent haul of fish.When he saw them leaping about in the net upon the rock he said: “O you most perverse creatures, when I piped you would not dance, but now that I have ceased you do so merrily.”

狼与小羊羔: 大力神与车夫
The Wolf and the Lamb: Hercules and the Wagoner

狼与小羊羔: 一个车夫驾着一辆货车在乡间的小路上前行。突然，车轮陷进了一条车辙道里。这个乡下车夫先是目瞪口呆地站在那儿看着货车，接着便只是大叫着要大力神现身帮忙。据说，大力神出现了，并对他说：“兄弟，用你的肩膀把车轮扛起来。赶好你的牛。等你自己尽了最大努力之后再向我求助，不然，只一味祈求是无济于事的。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A carter was driving a wagon along a country lane, when the wheels sank down deep into a rut.The rustic driver, stupefied and aghast, stood looking at the wagon, and did nothing but utter loud cries to Hercules to come and help him.Hercules, it is said, appeared and thus addressed him: “Put your shoulders to the wheels, my man.Goad on your bullocks, and never more pray to me for help, until you have done your best to help yourself, or depend upon it you will henceforth pray in vain.”

狼与小羊羔: 自助才是最好的帮助。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Self-help is the best help.

狼与小羊羔: 蚂蚁与蚱蜢
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Ants and the Grasshopper

狼与小羊羔: 冬日里的一个晴天，蚂蚁们正在晾晒夏天收集的粮食。一只饿得奄奄一息的蚱蜢路过，恳切地乞求分得一点食物。蚂蚁们问他：“你为什么不在夏天储存食物呢？”他回答道：“我没有足够的闲暇时间。我那些天要唱歌。”于是他们嘲弄说：“如果你整个夏天只知道傻乎乎地唱歌，那么冬天时必然要饿着肚子跳舞，饿着肚子睡觉啦。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: The ants were spending a fine winter’s day drying grain collected in the summertime.A Grasshopper, perishing with famine, passed by and earnestly begged for a little food.The Ants inquired of him, “Why did you not treasure up food during the summer?” He replied, “I had not leisure enough.I passed the days in singing.”They then said in derision: “If you were foolish enough to sing all the summer, you must dance supperless to bed in the winter.”

狼与小羊羔: 旅行者和他的狗
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Traveler and His Dog

狼与小羊羔: 一个旅行者正准备动身去旅行，看见他的狗站在门口伸懒腰。他严厉地问他：“你为什么还站在那里打哈欠呢？一切准备妥当，就等你了，赶快跟我走吧。”狗摇了摇自己的尾巴，回答道：“噢，主人！我早就准备好了，是我在等你啊。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A traveler about to set out on a journey saw his Dog stand at the door stretching himself.He asked him sharply: “Why do you stand there gaping?Everything is ready but you, so come with me instantly.”The Dog, wagging his tail, replied: “O, master!I am quite ready; it is you for whom I am waiting.”

狼与小羊羔: 闲散的人经常把耽搁的责任归咎到比他积极勤快的朋友身上。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The loiterer often blames delay on his more active friend.

狼与小羊羔: 狗和影子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Dog and the Shadow

狼与小羊羔: 一只狗，嘴里叼着块肉，正在过桥，桥下面是一条小溪。狗看见自己在水中的影子，以为那是另一只狗，那只狗嘴里叼的肉比他自己的还要大一倍。他立马把自己的那块肉扔掉，狠狠地扑向另一只狗，想从那儿抢到那块较大的肉。结果他两块肉都没有得到。因为他想要在水里抓到的那块肉，只是个倒影而已；而他自己的那块，也被水冲走了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A dog, crossing a bridge over a stream with a piece of flesh in his mouth, saw his own shadow in the water and took it for that of another Dog, with a piece of meat double his own in size.He immediately let go of his own, and fiercely attacked the other Dog to get his larger piece from him.He thus lost both: that which he grasped at in the water, because it was a shadow; and his own, because the stream swept it away.

狼与小羊羔: 鼹鼠和他的妈妈
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Mole and His Mother

狼与小羊羔: 一只鼹鼠，生下来眼睛就看不见，有一次他对妈妈说：“妈妈，我确信我能看见！”为了证明鼹鼠的错误，他妈妈在他面前放了几粒乳香，然后问他：“这是什么？”小鼹鼠说：“是一颗鹅卵石。”他妈妈大叫道：“我的儿啊，恐怕你不光是看不见，连嗅觉也已经失去了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A mole, a creature blind from birth, once said to his Mother: “I am sure than I can see, Mother!” In the desire to prove to him his mistake, his Mother placed before him a few grains of frankincense, and asked,“What is it?” The young Mole said, “It is a pebble.”His Mother exclaimed: “My son, I am afraid that you are not only blind, but that you have lost your sense of smell.”

狼与小羊羔: 牧人和丢失的公牛
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Herdsman and the Lost Bull

狼与小羊羔: 一个牧人在森林里放牧，结果一头小公牛犊从牧群里走失了。他找了很长时间，却一无所获。于是他发誓，只要能够找到偷小公牛犊的贼，他就供奉一只羊给赫米斯、潘以及森林的诸位守护神。过了一会儿，他走上一个小山丘，看见山脚下有只狮子正在吃他丢的那只小牛犊。看到这一幕，他吓得举起双手，仰望着天空，说道：“我刚发誓，如果捉到偷牛犊的贼，我愿供奉一只羊给森林的诸位守护神。但是，既然我已经发现了那个贼，我愿意放弃那头丢失的小公牛，此外再添上一头大公牛，只要我自己能安全地逃脱这狮子。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A herdsman tending his flock in a forest lost a Bull-calf from the fold.After a long and fruitless search, he made a vow that, if he could only discover the thief who had stolen the Calf, he would offer a lamb in sacrifice to Hermes, Pan, and the Guardian Deities of the forest.Not long afterwards, as he ascended a small hillock, he saw at its foot a Lion feeding on the Calf.Terrified at the sight, he lifted his eyes and his hands to heaven, and said: “Just now I vowed to offer a lamb to the Guardian Deities of the forest if I could only find out who had robbed me; but now that I have discovered the thief, I would willingly add a full-grown Bull to the Calf I have lost, if I may only secure my own escape from him in safety.”

狼与小羊羔: 兔子和乌龟
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Hare and the Tortoise

狼与小羊羔: 一天，兔子嘲笑乌龟腿短，行动缓慢。乌龟笑着回答说：“虽然你像风一样快，但是赛跑的话,我会赢你。”兔子认为乌龟说的话根本不可能，就答应了这个提议；他们一致同意由狐狸选择路线，并指定终点。在约定比赛的那天，两位一起出发了。乌龟一刻也不停歇，用缓慢而稳健的步伐，径直朝路线的终点前进。而兔子，却躺在路边，酣睡过去了。最后，兔子醒了，拼命地往前跑，但他看到乌龟已经到达了终点。乌龟经过一番劳累之后，正在舒服地小憩。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Hare one day ridiculed the short feet and slow pace of the Tortoise, who replied, laughing: “Though you be swift as the wind, I will beat you in a race.”The Hare, believing her assertion to be simply impossible, assented to the proposal; and they agreed that the Fox should choose the course and fix the goal.On the day appointed for the race the two started together.The Tortoise never for a moment stopped, but went on with a slow but steady pace straight to the end of the course.The Hare, lying down by the wayside, fell fast asleep. At last waking up, and moving as fast as he could, he saw the Tortoise had reached the goal, and was comfortably dozing after her fatigue.

狼与小羊羔: 速度慢没关系，只要脚步稳，就能赢得比赛。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Slow but steady wins the race.

狼与小羊羔: 石榴树、苹果树和荆棘
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Pomegranate, Apple-Tree, and Bramble

狼与小羊羔: 石榴树和苹果树争论谁最美丽。当它们吵得不可开交时，旁边树篱上的荆棘提高了自己的嗓门，自负地说：“拜托，我亲爱的朋友们，至少当着我的面，就停止这种徒劳无益的争论吧。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Pomegranate and Apple-Tree disputed as to which was the most beautiful.When their strife was at its height, a Bramble from the neighboring hedge lifted up its voice, and said in a boastful tone: “Pray, my dear friends, in my presence at least cease from such vain disputings.”

狼与小羊羔: 农夫和鹳
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Farmer and the Stork

狼与小羊羔: 一个农夫在刚刚播种的田里撒了很多网，许多来吃种子的鹤都被捉住了。其中还有一只鹳被捉住了。这只鹳在网里折断了腿，他诚恳地乞求农夫饶他一命。“求你饶了我，主人，”他说道，“这次就放了我吧。你就可怜可怜我折断的腿吧。还有，我不是鹤，我是一只鹳，是一种品性极好的鸟。你瞧，我多爱我的父母，我愿意为他们拼命干活。再看看我的羽毛——和鹤的羽毛完全不同。”农夫大笑着说：“你说的话也许都是真的，但我只知道，你和这些偷吃种子的鹤一起被捉到，那你就得和他们一起死。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Farmer placed nets on his newly sown plowlands and caught a number of Cranes, which came to pickup his seed.With them he trapped a Stork that had fractured his leg in the net and was earnestly beseeching the Farmer to spare his life.“Pray save me, Master,” he said, “and let me go free this once.My broken limb should excite your pity.Besides, I am no Crane, I am a Stork, a bird of excellent character; and see how I love and slave for my father and mother.Look too, at my feathers—they are not the least like those of a Crane.”The Farmer laughed aloud and said, “It may be all as you say, I only know this: I have taken you with these robbers, the Cranes, and you must die in their company.”

狼与小羊羔: 鸟以群分，物以类聚。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Birds of a feather flock together.

狼与小羊羔: 农夫与蛇
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Farmer and the Snake

狼与小羊羔: 一个冬天，有位农夫发现一条蛇冻僵了。他觉得蛇很可怜，便把它拿起来，放进了自己的怀里。蛇很快便被暖醒过来，恢复了它的本性，咬了它的恩人一口，让他受了致命伤。“哎，”农夫用最后一口气叹道，“我怜悯卑鄙之徒，活该遭恶报啊。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: One winter a Farmer found a Snake stiff and frozen with cold.He had compassion on it, and taking it up, placed it in his bosom.The Snake was quickly revived by the warmth, and resuming its natural instincts, bit its benefactor, inflicting on him a mortal wound.“Oh,” cried the Farmer with his last breath, “I am rightly served for pitying a scoundrel.”

狼与小羊羔: 再大的仁慈也无法约束忘恩负义之徒。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.

狼与小羊羔: 小鹿和他的妈妈
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Fawn and His Mother

狼与小羊羔: 有一次，一只小鹿问他的妈妈：“你比狗高大、敏捷,也更习惯于奔跑，你还有一对鹿角可以防御。那么，噢，妈妈！你为什么那么害怕猎犬呢？”鹿妈妈笑了笑，说道：“我的儿子，我非常清楚你说的都是真的。我确实拥有你刚说的那些优势，可是每当我听到即使一只狗在叫，我就感觉快要晕倒了，于是就尽全力飞快逃跑。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A young fawn once said to his Mother, “You are larger than a dog, and swifter, and more used to running, and you have your horns as a defense; why, then, O Mother! do the hounds frighten you so?”She smiled, and said: “I know full well, my son, that all you say is true.I have the advantages you mention, but when I hear even the bark of a single dog I feel ready to faint, and fly away as fast as I can.”

狼与小羊羔: 任何理由都不能给懦夫以勇气。
The Wolf and the Lamb: No arguments will give courage to the coward.

狼与小羊羔: 熊和狐狸
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Bear and the Fox

狼与小羊羔: 一只熊大力吹嘘自己仁慈，说在所有动物中，它对人类最心软，因为它非常尊重人类，甚至连人的尸体都不碰一下。一只狐狸听到这些话，笑着对它说：“噢！那么说你是愿意吃死人，而不是活人喽。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A bear boasted very much of his philanthropy, saying that of all animals he was the most tender in his regard for man, for he had such respect for him that he would not even touch his dead body.A Fox hearing these words said with a smile to the Bear, “Oh! that you would eat the dead and not the living.”

狼与小羊羔: 燕子和乌鸦
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Swallow and the Crow

狼与小羊羔: 燕子和乌鸦因为各自羽毛的事发生了争执。乌鸦说了这样一句话结束了这场争论：“你的羽毛在春天确实都很不错，但我的羽毛却能护我过冬。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Swallow and the Crow had a contention about their plumage.The Crow put an end to the dispute by saying, “Your feathers are all very well in the spring, but mine protect me against the winter.”

狼与小羊羔: 只能同甘不能共苦的朋友不值得交。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Fair weather friends are not worth much.

狼与小羊羔: 山震
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Mountain in Labor

狼与小羊羔: 一次，有座大山剧烈摇动。它发出巨大的吱嘎声和各种噪音，许多人从四面八方赶来观看到底发生了什么事。当他们焦急地聚集在那里，担心会发生什么可怕的灾难时，一只老鼠跑了出来。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A mountain was once greatly agitated.Loud groans and noises were heard, and crowds of people came from all parts to see what was the matter.While they were assembled in anxious expectation of some terrible calamity, out came a Mouse.

狼与小羊羔: 不要小题大做。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Don’t make much ado about nothing.

狼与小羊羔: 驴子、狐狸和狮子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Ass, the Fox, and the Lion

狼与小羊羔: 驴子和狐狸结成联盟共同防御敌人，到森林里捕猎。没走多远，他们就遇到了一头狮子。狐狸看到危险在即，便靠近狮子，许诺如果狮子保证不伤害自己，就帮他设计捕获驴子。接着，狐狸先是向驴子保证不会伤害他，然后把他带到了一个深坑前，安排让他掉了进去。狮子见驴子已然到手了，便立刻捉住了狐狸，然后在有空时开始大吃驴子。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The ass and the Fox, having entered into partnership together for their mutual protection, went out into the forest to hunt.They had not proceeded far when they met a Lion.The Fox, seeing imminent danger, approached the Lion and promised to contrive for him the capture of the Ass if the Lion would pledge his word not to harm the Fox.Then, upon assuring the Ass that he would not be injured, the Fox led him to a deep pit and arranged that he should fall into it.The Lion, seeing that the Ass was secured, immediately clutched the Fox, and attacked the Ass at his leisure.

狼与小羊羔: 乌龟和鹰
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Tortoise and the Eagle

狼与小羊羔: 一只乌龟懒洋洋地晒着太阳，她向海鸟们抱怨自己命苦，竟没有谁愿意教她飞翔。一只在附近盘旋的老鹰，听到了她的哀叹，问她如果能带她在空中飞翔，他会得到什么回报。“我会给你，”她说，“红海里的所有财富。”“那么我来教你飞翔。”老鹰说着，就用爪子抓着乌龟，带她几乎飞到了云端。突然，他放开了乌龟。乌龟落在一座高山上，壳被摔得粉碎。乌龟在临死时大喊道：“我活该落得这样的下场。要是我都能在云端展翅飞翔，那谁还会费力在地面上移动呢？”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A tortoise, lazily basking in the sun, complained to the seabirds of her hard fate, that no one would teach her to fly.An Eagle, hovering near, heard her lamentation and demanded what reward she would give him if he would take her aloft and float her in the air.“I will give you,” she said, “all the riches of the Red Sea.”“I will teach you to fly then,” said the Eagle; and taking her up in his talons, he carried her almost to the clouds. Suddenly he let her go, and she fell on a lofty mountain, dashing her shell to pieces.The Tortoise exclaimed in the moment of death: “I have deserved my present fate; for what had I to do with wings and clouds, who can with difficulty move about on the earth?”

狼与小羊羔: 如果人们事事都如愿，那他们也将常常遭遇毁灭。
The Wolf and the Lamb: If men had all they wished, they would be often ruined.

狼与小羊羔: 苍蝇和蜜罐
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Flies and the Honey-Pot

狼与小羊羔: 一群苍蝇被主妇房间里一罐打翻的蜂蜜所吸引。它们将脚浸在蜂蜜里，贪婪地吸吮着。然而，它们的脚却被蜂蜜粘住了，翅膀打不开，身体也解脱不了，最后窒息而死。在快断气的时候，它们喊道：“噢，我们是多么愚蠢啊，就为了这一点点的愉悦，竟毁了我们自己。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A number of Flies were attracted to a jar of honey which had been overturned in a housekeeper’s room, and placing their feet in it, ate greedily.Their feet, however, became so smeared with the honey that they could not use their wings, nor release themselves, and were suffocated.Just as they were expiring, they exclaimed, “O foolish creatures that we are, for the sake of a little pleasure we have destroyed ourselves.”

狼与小羊羔: 愉悦是用痛苦和创伤换来的。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Pleasure bought with pains, hurts.

狼与小羊羔: 人与狮子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Man and the Lion

狼与小羊羔: 一个人和一头狮子一路同行，穿越森林。很快，他们就开始各自吹嘘自己的力量和英勇远在对方之上。就在争辩之时，他们路过一座石雕像，刻的是“一头狮子被一个人勒死了”。旅行者便指着雕像说：“看那儿！我们人类多强大啊，我们甚至连万兽之王都征服了。”狮子回答道：“这个雕像是你们人类刻的。如果我们狮子也知道如何建造雕像的话，你看到的将是人类倒在狮子脚下的画面了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A man and a Lion traveled together through the forest.They soon began to boast of their respective superiority to each other in strength and prowess.As they were disputing, they passed a statue carved in stone, which represented “a Lion strangled by a Man.”The traveler pointed to it and said: “See there!How strong we are, and how we prevail over even the king of beasts.”The Lion replied: “This statue was made by one of you men.If we Lions knew how to erect statues, you would see the Man placed under the paw of the Lion.”

狼与小羊羔: 新故事一讲，旧故事减色。
The Wolf and the Lamb: One story is good, till another is told.

狼与小羊羔: 农夫与鹤群
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Farmer and the Cranes

狼与小羊羔: 几只鹤在刚刚播种过小麦的田地上觅食。有好长一段时间，农夫只是挥舞着空弹弓，恫吓着把它们赶跑；但是当这些鹤发现，弹弓不过是在空中晃晃而已时，它们就不理不睬，也不飞走了。看到这一情景，农夫便把他的弹弓装上了石头，杀死了一大群鹤。其余的鸟立即离开了农夫的田地，并互相大叫道：“我们是时候该离开这里去小人国了。因为这个农夫已经不再满足于仅仅吓吓我们，而是开始认真地向我们施展他的本事了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: Some cranes made their feeding grounds on some plowlands newly sown with wheat.For a long time the Farmer, brandishing an empty sling, chased them away by the terror he inspired; but when the birds found that the sling was only swung in the air, they ceased to take any notice of it and would not move.The Farmer, on seeing this, charged his sling with stones, and killed a great number.The remaining birds at once forsook his fields, crying to each other, “It is time for us to be off to Liliput: for this man is no longer content to scare us, but begins to show us in earnest what he can do.”

狼与小羊羔: 如果语言不够有力，拳头必将接踵而至。
The Wolf and the Lamb: If words suffice not, blows must follow.

狼与小羊羔: 驴和哈巴狗
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Ass and the Lapdog

狼与小羊羔: 一个人养了一头驴和一条长得非常漂亮的马耳他哈巴狗。驴被丢在栏舍里，有充足的燕麦和干草可以吃，就像其他驴一样。哈巴狗会耍很多把戏，深得主人喜爱。主人经常爱抚它，几乎每次出去吃饭都会给它捎回一些好吃的。然而，驴要干很多活，要拉磨磨玉米面，要从森林驮木材或是从农场驮重物回来。它经常哀叹自己命苦，老拿自己的命运和哈巴狗的奢侈、懒惰进行对比。终于有一天，它挣断了缰绳，飞奔到主人的房子里，肆无忌惮地乱踢蹄子，活蹦乱跳地尽力讨好主人。然后，驴效仿之前看到的哈巴狗的做法，在主人身边跳来跳去。但它却弄坏了餐桌，把餐桌上所有的盘子都打得粉碎。接着，驴试图舔它的主人，跳到他的背上。仆人们听到奇怪的吵闹声，发现主人有危险，连忙赶过去救他，并对驴棍棒相加，把它赶回了栏舍。当驴回到栏舍时，已经快被打死了，便哀叹道：“我这都是自讨苦吃啊！为什么我不满足于和其他伙伴们一起干活，却想要像那条没用的小哈巴狗一样整天无所事事啊！”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A man had an Ass, and a Maltese Lapdog, a very great beauty.The Ass was left in a stable and had plenty of oats and hay to eat, just as any other Ass would.The Lapdog knew many tricks and was a great favorite with his master, who often fondled him and seldom went out to dine without bringing him home some tidbit to eat.The Ass, on the contrary, had much work to do, in grinding the corn-mill, and in carrying wood from the forest, or burdens from the farm.He often lamented his own hard fate and contrasted it with the luxury and idleness of the Lapdog, till at last one day he broke his cords and halter, and galloped into his master’s house, kicking up his heels without measure, and frisking and fawning as well as he could.He next tried to jump about his master as he had seen the Lapdog do, but he broke the table and smashed all the dishes upon it to atoms.He then attempted to lick his master, and jumped upon his back.The servants, hearing the strange hubbub and perceiving the danger of their master, quickly relieved him, and drove out the Ass to his stable with kicks and clubs and cuffs.The Ass, as he returned to his stall beaten nearly to death, thus lamented: “I have brought it all on myself!Why could I not have been contented to labor with my companions, and not wish to be idle all the day like that useless little Lapdog!”

狼与小羊羔: 一个人满足于自己的命运好过去追求一些并不适合自己的东西。
The Wolf and the Lamb: To be satisfied with one’s lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.

狼与小羊羔: 母狮子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Lioness

狼与小羊羔: 田野里的野兽们大肆争论着哪种动物最配得到一胎生的幼崽数目最多这个赞誉。野兽们吵吵嚷嚷地冲到母狮子面前，请她来解决纷争。“你呢，”野兽们问道，“一胎能生几头小公狮子？”母狮子嘲笑他们道：“哎呀！我一胎只生一头，但这绝对是一只纯种的狮子。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A controversy prevailed among the beasts of the field as to which of the animals deserved the most credit for producing the greatest number of whelps at a birth.They rushed clamorously into the presence of the Lioness and demanded of her the settlement of the dispute.“And you,” they said, “how many sons have you at a birth?’ The Lioness laughed at them, and said: “Why!I have only one; but that one is altogether a thoroughbred lion.”

狼与小羊羔: 事物的价值在于品质，而不在于数量。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The value is in the worth, not in the number.

狼与小羊羔: 吹牛的旅行者
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Boasting Traveler

狼与小羊羔: 一个曾在外国旅行过的人返回自己的国家后，大肆吹嘘自己在各地旅行时的各种精彩英勇事迹。其中一件是说他在罗得岛时跳得相当远，当时无人能及。罗得岛的许多人都看见他跳了，他们都算是见证人。一个旁观者打断他说：“喂，我的好伙计，如果你所说的全部属实，就不需要什么见证人了。姑且把这里当作罗得岛，你跳给我们看看吧。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A man who had traveled in foreign lands boasted very much, on returning to his own country, of the many wonderful and heroic feats he had performed in the different places he had visited.Among other things, he said that when he was at Rhodes he had leaped to such a distance that no man of his day could leap anywhere near him as to that, there were in Rhodes many persons who saw him do it and whom he could call as witnesses.One of the bystanders interrupted him, saying: “Now, my good man, if this be all true there is no need of witnesses.Suppose this to be Rhodes, and leap for us.”

狼与小羊羔: 真正能干的人不需要自夸。
The Wolf and the Lamb: He who does a thing well does not need to boast.

狼与小羊羔: 猫和公鸡
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Cat and the Cock

狼与小羊羔: 一只猫抓到了一只公鸡，便思忖着如何找个合理的借口把公鸡吃掉。猫指责公鸡在夜间啼叫，打扰人们休息，令人讨厌。公鸡自我辩解说，这样做是为了人们好，这样他们才能按时起床去干活。猫回答说：“虽然你有很多冠冕堂皇的理由，但我也不能一直不吃晚饭啊。”说完，猫就把公鸡吃掉了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Cat caught a Cock, and pondered how he might find a reasonable excuse for eating him.He accused him of being a nuisance to men by crowing in the nighttime and not permitting them to sleep.The Cock defended himself by saying that he did this for the benefit of men, that they might rise in time for their labors.The Cat replied, “Although you abound in specious apologies, I shall not remain supperless”; and he made a meal of him.

狼与小羊羔: 小猪、绵羊和山羊
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Piglet, the Sheep, and the Goat

狼与小羊羔: 一头小猪同一只山羊和一只绵羊一起被关在了畜栏里。有一次，当牧羊人抓住小猪时，小猪又是咕噜又是尖叫，奋力反抗。绵羊和山羊对猪的惨叫声很不满，说道：“他也经常抓我们，但我们可从不大喊大叫的。”小猪回答说：“抓你们和抓我是完全不一样的。他抓你们，只不过是要剪你们的羊毛或挤奶，而他抓我则是来要我的命的啊。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Piglet was shut up in a fold yard with a Goat and a Sheep.On one occasion when the shepherd laid hold of him, he grunted and squeaked and resisted violently.The Sheep and the Goat complained of his distressing cries, saying, “He often handles us, and we do not cry out.”To this the Piglet replied, “Your handling and mine are very different things.He catches you only for your wool, or your milk, but he lays hold on me for my very life.”

狼与小羊羔: 男孩和榛子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Boy and the Filberts

狼与小羊羔: 一个男孩把手伸进一个装满榛子的罐子里。他尽可能多地抓了满满一把榛子，但是当他试着把手拔出来时，却被罐颈卡住了。他不愿丢掉榛子，手又拿不出来。他急得大哭起来，因失望而悲痛不已。一个旁观者对他说：“如果你拿一半榛子就知足的话，就能毫不费劲地把手抽出来了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Boy put his hand into a pitcher full of filberts.He grasped as many as he could possibly hold, but when he tried to pull out his hand, he was prevented from doing so by the neck of the pitcher.Unwilling to lose his filberts, and yet unable to withdraw his hand, he burst into tears and bitterly lamented his disappointment.A bystander said to him, “Be satisfied with half the quantity, and you will readily draw out your hand.”

狼与小羊羔: 一次不要贪太多。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Do not attempt too much at once.

狼与小羊羔: 恋爱中的狮子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Lion in Love

狼与小羊羔: 一头狮子向一位伐木工的女儿求婚。虽然女儿的父亲不想答应，但又不敢拒绝狮子的请求，于是想出了一个摆脱狮子无理要求的权宜之计。伐木工表示自已愿意接受狮子对女儿的求婚，但是有一个条件：狮子允许他拔掉它的牙齿，砍掉它的爪子，因为他女儿非常害怕这两样东西。狮子欣然接受了这个建议。但是，当失去牙齿和利爪的狮子再来求婚时，伐木工不再惧怕它，便用木棍猛打狮子，把它赶回了森林。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Lion demanded the daughter of a woodcutter in marriage.The Father, unwilling to grant, and yet afraid to refuse his request, hit upon this expedient to rid himself of his importunities.He expressed his willingness to accept the Lion as the suitor of his daughter on one condition: that he should allow him to extract his teeth, and cut off his claws, as his daughter was fearfully afraid of both.The Lion cheerfully assented to the proposal.But when the toothless, clawless Lion returned to repeat his request, the Woodman, no longer afraid, set upon him with his club, and drove him away into the forest.

狼与小羊羔: 雇农与蛇
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Laborer and the Snake

狼与小羊羔: 一条蛇在一间农舍的门廊附近打了一个洞，把农舍主的婴儿给咬死了。父亲痛失爱子，下决心要把蛇杀死。第二天，当蛇出洞觅食时，他拿起斧头就砍，但由于他砍得太匆忙，没有砍到蛇的头，只砍断了蛇的尾巴梢。过了一段时间，农舍主害怕蛇也会来咬自己，就试图跟蛇和解，放了一些面包和盐在蛇洞里。蛇发出轻微的嘶嘶声，说道：“从此以后，我们之间不会有和平。因为，我无论何时看到你，都会想起自己断掉的尾巴；而你无论何时看到我，也会想起你死去的儿子。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Snake, having made his hole close to the porch of a cottage, inflicted a mortal bite on the Cottager’s infant son.Grieving over his loss, the father resolved to kill the Snake.The next day, when it came out of its hole for food, he took up his axe, but by swinging too hastily, missed its head and cut off only the end of its tail.After some time the Cottager, afraid that the Snake would bite him also, endeavored to make peace, and placed some bread and salt in the hole.The Snake, slightly hissing, said: “There can henceforth be no peace between us; for whenever I see you I shall remember the loss of my tail, and whenever you see me you will be thinking of the death of your son.”

狼与小羊羔: 面对伤痛的始作俑者，没有人能真正忘记那些伤痛。
The Wolf and the Lamb: No one truly forgets injuries in the presence of him who caused the injury.

狼与小羊羔: 披着羊皮的狼
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Wolf in Sheep’s Clothing

狼与小羊羔: 从前，有一只狼决定乔装打扮，以便能更容易地猎取到食物。于是，它披上了一张羊皮，和羊群一起吃草。凭着这番装扮，它骗过了牧羊人。夜里，牧羊人把它和羊群一起关进了羊栏，并把栏门紧锁起来，使入口处彻底安全。可是到了深夜，牧羊人为了准备第二天吃的羊肉，又回到了羊栏。结果，他误捉了那只披着羊皮的狼而不是真正的羊，即刻就把它杀了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Once upon a time a Wolf resolved to disguise his appearance in order to secure food more easily. Encased in the skin of a sheep, he pastured with the flock deceiving the shepherd by his costume.In the evening he was shut up by the shepherd in the fold; the gate was closed, and the entrance made thoroughly secure.But the shepherd, returning to the fold during the night to obtain meat for the next day, mistakenly caught up the Wolf instead of a sheep, and killed him instantly.

狼与小羊羔: 自作自受。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Harm seek, harm find.

狼与小羊羔: 驴和骡子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Ass and the Mule

狼与小羊羔: 一个赶骡人启程去旅行，他赶着一头驴和一头骡子，它们都身负重物。只要是在平原上走，驴驮着它的货物是很轻松的，但当驴开始爬陡峭的山路时就感觉力不从心了。于是，驴恳求它的同伴帮它分担一小部分货物，以便自己能够将其余的货物驮回家。但是，骡子丝毫不理会它的请求。过了不久，驴不堪重负，倒下死了。在如此荒凉的地方，赶骡人不知道还有什么别的东西能驮载货物，便把之前驴驮的货物加在了骡子的背上，并把他剥掉的驴皮放在了所有货物的最上面。骡子在重压之下呻吟，自言自语道：“我是活该受这罪啊。如果当初我愿意在驴需要帮助的时候稍稍帮它一下，现在我也不至于承受如此重负，不仅要驮着它的货物，还要驮着它的皮。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A muleteer set forth on a journey, driving before him an Ass and a Mule, both well laden.The Ass, as long as he traveled along the plain, carried his load with ease, but when he began to ascend the steep path of the mountain, felt his load to be more than he could bear.He entreated his companion to relieve him of a small portion, that he might carry home the rest; but the Mule paid no attention to the request.The Ass shortly afterwards fell down dead under his burden.Not knowing what else to do in so wild a region, the Muleteer placed upon the Mule the load carried by the Ass in addition to his own, and at the top of all placed the hide of the Ass, after he had skinned him.The Mule, groaning beneath his heavy burden, said to himself: “I am treated according to my deserts.If I had only been willing to assist the Ass a little in his need, I should not now be bearing, together with his burden, himself as well.”

狼与小羊羔: 防范胜于补救。
The Wolf and the Lamb: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

狼与小羊羔: 青蛙祈求一位国王
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Frogs Asking for a King

狼与小羊羔: 青蛙们因没有确立统治者而难过，于是派遣使者们前去向朱庇特乞求一位国王。朱庇特感受到了青蛙们的真诚，便向湖里抛下了一根巨大的原木。青蛙们被原木掉落下来溅起的水花吓坏了，都藏到了水塘的深处。但当他们一发现这根巨大的原木一动不动时，就再次游到水面上来，不再害怕了。他们爬上来，开始轻蔑地蹲坐在原木上。过了一阵子，青蛙们因被指派了这么个如此迟钝的统治者而感觉自己受到了不公正的待遇，于是他们再次派一个代表团前去见朱庇特，祈求他再指派一位别的君主来统治他们。于是朱庇特派了一条鳗鱼去统治他们。当青蛙们发现鳗鱼随和、善良的本性时，就又第三次去找朱庇特，乞求他再给他们挑选一位国王。朱庇特对青蛙们的种种抱怨感到不悦，便派遣苍鹭去当他们的国王。苍鹭成天都捕食青蛙，直到湖里再也没有青蛙呱呱叫了为止。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Frogs, grieved at having no established Ruler, sent ambassadors to Jupiter entreating for a King. Perceiving their simplicity, he cast down a huge log into the lake.The Frogs were terrified at the splash occasioned by its fall and hid themselves in the depths of the pool.But as soon as they realized that the huge log was motionless, they swam again to the top of the water, dismissed their fears, climbed up, and began squatting on it in contempt.After some time they began to think themselves ill-treated in the appointment of so inert a Ruler, and sent a second deputation to Jupiter to pray that he would set over them another sovereign.He then gave them an Eel to govern them.When the Frogs discovered his easy good nature, they sent yet a third time to Jupiter to beg him to choose for them still another King.Jupiter, displeased with all their complaints, sent a Heron, who preyed upon the Frogs day by day till there were none left to croak upon the lake.

狼与小羊羔: 男孩和青蛙
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Boys and the Frogs

狼与小羊羔: 几个男孩子在池塘边玩耍，看到水中有许多青蛙，于是便开始朝青蛙扔石头。男孩们砸死了几只青蛙。这时，有一只青蛙把头伸出水面，哭喊道：“孩子们，求你们停下来吧，这对你们来说是玩耍，对我们却意味着死亡啊。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: Some Boys, playing near a pond, saw a number of Frogs in the water and began to pelt them with stones.They killed several of them, when one of the Frogs, lifting his head out of the water, cried out: “Pray stop, my boys: what is sport to you, is death to us.”

狼与小羊羔: 生病的牡鹿
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Sick Stag

狼与小羊羔: 一头生病的牡鹿躺在牧场一个安静的角落里。牡鹿的众多伙伴都过来问候他，每个伙伴还自取了一份原本放在那里供这只牡鹿食用的食物。因此，牡鹿死了，不是死于疾病，而是死于没有食物来维持生计。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Sick Stag lay down in a quiet corner of its pasture ground.His companions came in great numbers to inquire after his health, and each one helped himself to a share of the food which had been placed for his use; so that he died, not from his sickness, but from the failure of the means of living.

狼与小羊羔: 结交损友，损害大于收益。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Evil companions bring more hurt than profit.

狼与小羊羔: 盐商和他的驴子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Salt Merchant and His Ass

狼与小羊羔: 一个商贩骑着他的驴子到海边去买盐。在商贩回家的路上有一条小溪。他的驴子一失足，不小心摔倒在了小溪里。等驴子再次站起来时，由于水溶解了麻袋中的盐，它背的货物变轻了许多。商贩原路返回，又把驮篮里装满了盐，这次比上次装的盐还要多。当他又来到小溪前时，驴子在同一个地方故意跌倒了。由于货物的重量大减，驴子重新站了起来，还得意地叫着，好像如愿以偿了似的。商贩看穿了驴子的诡计，便第三次赶着驴子回到了海边。这次他没有买盐，而是买了大量的海绵。等又到小溪的时候，驴子故伎重演，故意跌倒了，可海绵吸水后膨胀了起来，大大增加了它背负的重量。于是，驴子自食其果，因为现在它背上驮着的重负是之前的两倍。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Peddler drove his Ass to the seashore to buy salt.His road home lay across a stream into which his Ass, making a false step, fell by accident and rose up again with his load considerably lighter, as the water melted the sack.The Peddler retraced his steps and refilled his panniers with a larger quantity of salt than before. When he came again to the stream, the Ass fell down on purpose in the same spot, and, regaining his feet with the weight of his load much diminished, brayed triumphantly as if he had obtained what he desired.The Peddler saw through his trick and drove him for the third time to the coast, where he bought a cargo of sponges instead of salt.The Ass, again playing the fool, fell down on purpose when he reached the stream, but the sponges became swollen with water, greatly increasing his load.And thus his trick recoiled on him, for he now carried on his back a double burden.

狼与小羊羔: 公牛和屠夫
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Oxen and the Butchers

狼与小羊羔: 很久以前，公牛企图杀死屠夫，因为屠夫从事的行业有害于公牛这个种族。一天，公牛们集合在一起，准备实施它们的计划，并为这场角逐磨尖了自己的犄角。但是，它们中的一头非常老的公牛（因为它耕过很多田地）说道：“这些屠夫的确是屠杀我们的，但是他们屠杀时手法熟练，没有给我们带来不必要的疼痛。如果我们除掉了他们，我们将落入手法不精的屠夫之手，这样我要死亡两次：因为你可能清楚，尽管所有的屠夫都该死，但是人类是永远不会缺少牛肉的。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Oxen once upon a time sought to destroy the Butchers, who practiced a trade destructive to their race. They assembled on a certain day to carry out their purpose, and sharpened their horns for the contest.But one of them who was exceedingly old (for many a field had he plowed) thus spoke: “These Butchers, it is true, slaughter us, but they do so with skillful hands, and with no unnecessary pain.If we get rid of them, we shall fall into the hands of unskillful operators, and thus suffer a double death: for you may be assured, that though all the Butchers should perish, yet will men never want beef.”

狼与小羊羔: 不要急于将一种灾祸换成另一种灾祸。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.

狼与小羊羔: 狮子、老鼠和狐狸
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Lion, the Mouse, and the Fox

狼与小羊羔: 夏日里，一头狮子因酷暑难耐而倍感疲乏，很快就在自己的洞穴里睡着了。一只老鼠从狮子的鬃毛和耳朵上跑过，把狮子从沉睡中吵醒了。狮子站起来，极为愤怒地抖了抖身子，然后搜寻洞穴的每个角落，要找那只老鼠。一只狐狸看到狮子这样，便说：“你这么威武的一头狮子，竟怕起一只老鼠来了。”“我不是怕老鼠，”狮子说，“我是憎恶他的放肆和无礼。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Lion, fatigued by the heat of a summer’s day, fell fast asleep in his den.A Mouse ran over his mane and ears and woke him from his slumbers.He rose up and shook himself in great wrath, and searched every corner of his den to find the Mouse.A Fox seeing him said: “A fine Lion you are, to be frightened of a Mouse.”“’Tis not the Mouse I fear,” said the Lion; “I resent his familiarity and ill breeding.”

狼与小羊羔: 小自由，大冒犯。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Little liberties are great offenses.

狼与小羊羔: 徒劳的寒鸦
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Vain Jackdaw

狼与小羊羔: 据说，朱庇特决定要为众鸟立一个君主，并宣布在某一天让所有鸟类都去拜见他。届时，他将在众鸟中亲自选定最美的一只鸟为王。寒鸦知道自己丑陋，便寻遍森林和田野，收集那些从他同伴们的翅膀上掉下来的羽毛，然后将羽毛插遍自己的全身各处，希望因此能让自己成为众鸟中最美的那只。约定的日子到了，众鸟都聚集到了朱庇特面前，寒鸦也身着满是羽毛的华丽服饰闪亮登场。但是，当朱庇特因寒鸦的美丽羽毛而提议立寒鸦为王时，众鸟愤怒地表示抗议。每只鸟都从寒鸦身上把属于自己的羽毛拔了下来，而仅留给他一只寒鸦的原貌。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Jupiter determined, it is said, to create a sovereign over the birds, and made proclamation that on a certain day they should all present themselves before him, when he would himself choose the most beautiful among them to be king.The Jackdaw, knowing his own ugliness, searched through the woods and fields, and collected the feathers which had fallen from the wings of his companions, and stuck them in all parts of his body, hoping thereby to make himself the most beautiful of all.When the appointed day arrived, and the birds had assembled before Jupiter, the Jackdaw also made his appearance in his many feathered finery.But when Jupiter proposed to make him king because of the beauty of his plumage, the birds indignantly protested, and each plucked from him his own feathers, leaving the Jackdaw nothing but a Jackdaw.

狼与小羊羔: 牧羊人和野山羊
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Goatherd and the Wild Goats

狼与小羊羔: 黄昏时分，一个牧羊人正赶着他的羊群离开牧场。他发现有些野山羊混进了羊群里，于是，晚上他就把它们和自己的羊群关在了一起。第二天，雪下得非常大。因此，牧羊人没办法赶羊群去它们常去的牧场，而不得不把它们关在羊栏里。牧羊人只给自己的山羊足够维持生命的食物，却用更为充足的食物来喂养那些新进来的野山羊，希望以此吸引它们留下来，并将它们据为己有。当雪开始融化时，牧羊人将所有的羊都放出来吃草，那些野山羊则尽全力地飞奔着跑上了山。牧羊人斥责它们忘恩负义离开他，想当初降暴雪时，他曾细心地照料它们，胜过自己的羊群。其中一只野山羊转过头来，对他说：“这正是我们这么小心谨慎的原因，你昨天对我们比对你喂养了这么长时间的羊都更好，那么如果我们后面来了其他羊的话，显然你也会同样地更喜欢它们。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Goatherd, driving his flock from their pasture at eventide, found some Wild Goats mingled among them, and shut them up together with his own for the night.The next day it snowed very hard, so that he could not take the herd to their usual feeding places, but was obliged to keep them in the fold.He gave his own goats just sufficient food to keep them alive, but fed the strangers more abundantly in the hope of enticing them to stay with him and of making them his own.When the thaw set in, he led them all out to feed, and the Wild Goats scampered away as fast as they could to the mountains.The Goatherd scolded them ingratitude in leaving him, when during the storm he had taken more care of them than of his own herd. One of them, turning about, said to him: “That is the very reason why we are so cautious; for if you yesterday treated us better than the Goats you have had so long, it is plain also that if others came after us, you would in the same manner prefer them to ourselves.”

狼与小羊羔: 为了新朋友而牺牲老朋友是不能免遭惩罚的。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Old friends cannot with impunity be sacrificed for new ones.

狼与小羊羔: 顽皮的狗
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Mischievous Dog

狼与小羊羔: 有一条狗，每遇到一个人，总会悄悄跑上前，跟在人家的后面，然后趁其不备突然咬他们。狗的主人在它的脖子上挂了一个铃铛，这样不管这条狗去哪里,都可以告知别人它的存在。狗以为铃铛是荣誉勋章的标志，倍感自豪，便挂着个铃铛在集市上叮叮当当地四处转悠。一天，一只老猎犬对这条狗说：“你为什么要这样出尽洋相呢？相信我，你身上挂的铃铛绝不是什么荣誉勋章，恰恰相反，它是耻辱的标志，告知所有人你是条粗野的狗而注意避让。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Dog used to run up quietly to the heels of everyone he met, and to bite them without notice.His master suspended a bell about his neck so that the Dog might give notice of his presence wherever he went.Thinking it a mark of distinction, the Dog grew proud of his bell and went tinkling it all over the marketplace.One day an old hound said to him: “Why do you make such an exhibition of yourself?That bell that you carry is not, believe me, any order of merit, but on the contrary a mark of disgrace, a public notice to all men to avoid you as an ill mannered dog.”

狼与小羊羔: 声名狼籍常被误认为是鼎鼎大名。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.

狼与小羊羔: 丢了尾巴的狐狸
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Fox Who Had Lost His Tail

狼与小羊羔: 一只被困在陷阱里的狐狸成功逃脱了，但却为此失去了自己的尾巴。从那以后，狐狸因受到别人的羞辱和嘲笑而感觉自己的生活是个包袱。于是，他谋划着让其他所有的狐狸都相信没有尾巴更有吸引力，从而弥补他自己的缺失。他召集了很多狐狸，并公开向他们建议切断他们的尾巴，说没有尾巴不仅能让他们看起来更好看，而且还可以摆脱给他们造成极大不便的尾巴的重量。其中一只狐狸打断他，对他说：“朋友，如果你自己没有失去尾巴，你可能就不会这样来建议我们了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Fox caught in a trap escaped, but in so doing lost his tail.Thereafter, feeling his life a burden from the shame and ridicule to which he was exposed, he schemed to convince all the other foxes that being tailless was much more attractive, thus making up for his own deprivation.He assembled a good many foxes and publicly advised them to cut off their tails, saying that they would not only look much better without them, but that they would get rid of the weight of the brush, which was a very great inconvenience.One of them interrupting him said, “If you had not yourself lost your tail, my friend, you would not thus counsel us.”

狼与小羊羔: 男孩和荨麻
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Boy and the Nettles

狼与小羊羔: 一个男孩被荨麻扎到了。他跑回家告诉他的妈妈：“我只是轻轻地碰了它一下，它却把我扎得这么疼。”“这恰恰是它扎痛你的原因。”妈妈说道,“下次你再碰荨麻时，就大胆地抓住它，这样它在你的手里就会像丝绸一样柔软，根本扎不痛你了。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Boy was stung by a Nettle.He ran home and told his Mother, saying, “Although it hurts me very much, I only touched it gently.”“That was just why it stung you,” said his Mother.“The next time you touch a Nettle, grasp it boldly, and it will be soft as silk to your hand, and not in the least hurt you.”

狼与小羊羔: 不管做什么，都要竭尽全力。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Whatever you do, do with all your might.

狼与小羊羔: 男人和他的两个情人
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Man and His Two Sweethearts

狼与小羊羔: 一个头发开始发白的中年男人，同时追求着两个女人。这两个女人，一个年轻，另一个则上了年纪。那位年长的女子，因羞于被比自己年轻的男人追求，便提出了一个条件：不论她的这位追求者什么时候来看望她，她都要拔掉他的一部分黑发。那位年轻的女子却相反，她不想做一个老头的妻子，便也同样狂热地把她能在男人头上找到的所有白头发都拔掉了。就这样，夹在两个女子之间,这个男人很快发现他头上一根头发都没有了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: A middle-aged man, whose hair had begun to turn gray, courted two women at the same time.One of them was young, and the other well advanced in years.The elder woman, ashamed to be courted by a man younger than herself, made a point, whenever her admirer visited her, to pull out some portion of his black hairs.The younger, on the contrary, not wishing to become the wife of an old man, was equally zealous in removing every gray hair she could find.Thus it came to pass that between them both he very soon found that he had not a hair left on his head.

狼与小羊羔: 想取悦所有人，必将一个人也取悦不了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.

狼与小羊羔: 天文学家
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Astronomer

狼与小羊羔: 有一个天文学家，他常常晚上出去观测星星。一天晚上，他在野外闲逛时，因全神贯注定睛看天空，竟意外地跌入了一口深井里。因为身上有多处伤口和擦伤，他哀叹着痛哭不已，并同时大声呼救。一个邻居跑到井边，弄明白事情的经过后说：“听着，老伙计，你努力探究天上有什么的时候，怎么不留神看看地上有什么呢？”
The Wolf and the Lamb: An Astronomer used to go out at night to observe the stars.One evening, as he wandered through the suburbs with his whole attention fixed on the sky, he fell accidentally into a deep well.While he lamented and bewailed his sores and bruises, and cried loudly for help, a neighbor ran to the well, and learning what had happened said: “Hark ye, old fellow, why, in striving to pry into what is in heaven, do you not manage to see what is on earth?”

狼与小羊羔: 狼与羊
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Wolves and the Sheep

狼与小羊羔: “为什么我们之间总是存在着恐惧和杀戮呢？”狼对羊说道，“那些作恶多端的狗要负很大的责任。每次我们一靠近你们，那些狗就汪汪叫；我们还没对你们造成任何伤害，他们就来攻击我们。只要你们把他们从身边打发走，没准儿我们之间马上就能缔结和平与和解条约了。”可怜又愚蠢的羊轻而易举就上当受骗了，他们打发走了狗。于是狼便随心所欲地吃掉了那群失去保护的羊。
The Wolf and the Lamb: “Why should there always be this fear and slaughter between us?” said the Wolves to the Sheep. “Those evil-disposed Dogs have much to answer for.They always bark whenever we approach you and attack us before we have done any harm.If you would only dismiss them from your heels, there might soon be treaties of peace and reconciliation between us.”The Sheep, poor silly creatures, were easily beguiled and dismissed the Dogs, whereupon the Wolves destroyed the unguarded flock at their own pleasure.

狼与小羊羔: 老妇人与医生
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Old Woman and the Physician

狼与小羊羔: 一位老妇人失明了，请来医生给她治眼睛。她在证人面前和医生达成协议：如果医生治好了她的失明，他将从她那儿得到一笔钱，但如果她还是看不见，她就什么都不用给他。协议达成后，医生一次次来给老妇人的眼睛上药膏。每次上门他都拿走一些东西，就这样一点点地偷走了老妇人的所有家当。等医生把老妇人的东西都拿走后，他治好了老妇人的眼睛，并向她索要之前允诺的报酬。重获光明的老妇人看到家中空无一物，便什么也不愿给他。医生坚持要自己的酬劳，老妇人还是不给，于是医生将她告到法官那里。老妇人站在法庭上辩解道：“这个人说的话是属实的，我的确答应过他，自己若重获光明会给他一笔钱，但如果我还是看不见，我就什么都不用给他。现在他宣称将我的眼疾治好了。可是正相反，我敢肯定我依然看不见，因为我失明前还看到屋子里有各种财物和值钱的东西，但现在，虽然他发誓说已经治好了我的失明，可我还是一件东西都看不见。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: An Old Woman having lost the use of her eyes, called in a Physician to heal them, and made this bargain with him in the presence of witnesses: that if he should cure her blindness, he should receive from her a sum of money; but if her infirmity remained, she should give him nothing.This agreement being made, the Physician, time after time, applied his salve to her eyes, and on every visit took something away, stealing all her property little by little.And when he had got all she had, he healed her and demanded the promised payment.The Old Woman, when she recovered her sight and saw none of her goods in her house, would give him nothing.The Physician insisted on his claim, and as she still refused, summoned her before the Judge.The Old Woman, standing up in the Court, argued: “This man here speaks the truth in what he says; for I did promise to give him a sum of money if I should recover my sight: but if I continued blind, I was to give him nothing.Now he declares that I am healed.I on the contrary affirm that I am still blind; for when I lost the use of my eyes, I saw in my house various chattels and valuable goods; but now, though he swears I am cured of my blindness, I am not able to see a single thing in it.”

狼与小羊羔: 斗鸡和老鹰
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Fighting Cocks and the Eagle

狼与小羊羔: 两只斗鸡为了争夺农家庭院的控制权而正在恶战。最后，其中一只让另一只落败而逃。那只斗败的公鸡偷偷躲了起来，藏在一个安静的角落里，而那只胜利的公鸡则拍打着翅膀，飞上一座高墙，得意洋洋地放开嗓门打起鸣来。一只掠过天空的老鹰突然猛扑向这只公鸡，用利爪将其捉走了。那只战败的公鸡立刻从角落里跑了出来，从此毫无争议地控制了庭院。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Two game cocks were fiercely fighting for the mastery of the farmyard.One at last put the other to flight.The vanquished Cock skulked away and hid himself in a quiet corner, while the conqueror, flying up to a high wall, flapped his wings and crowed exultingly with all his might.An Eagle sailing through the air pounced upon him and carried him off in his talons.The vanquished Cock immediately came out of his corner, and ruled henceforth with undisputed mastery.

狼与小羊羔: 骄兵必败。
The Wolf and the Lamb: Pride goes before destruction.

狼与小羊羔: 战马和磨坊主
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Charger and the Miller

狼与小羊羔: 一匹战马年迈体弱，便被送到了一个磨坊里去干活，不再奔赴战场。但是，当这匹战马因不能再上战场而被迫去拉磨时，它又为自己命运的改变而深感悲哀。回想起昔日的身份地位，它说道：“啊！磨坊主啊，我的确曾亲历战场，全副武装，身边还有一个随从负责照料我，可现在，我不明白，到底是什么使我痛苦地放弃战场而选择了磨坊。”“够了，”磨坊主对马说道，“别再唠叨过去的事了，忍受命运的起伏是所有生物的共同命运。”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Charger, feeling the infirmities of age, was sent to work in a mill instead of going out to battle.But when he was compelled to grind instead of serving in the wars, he bewailed his change of fortune and called to mind his former state, saying, “Ah! Miller, I had indeed to go campaigning before, but I was barbed from counter to tail, and a man went along to groom me; and now I cannot understand what ailed me to prefer the mill before the battle.”“Forbear,” said the Miller to him, “harping on what was of  yore, for it is the common lot of mortals to sustain the ups and downs of fortune.”

狼与小羊羔: 狐狸和猴子
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Fox and the Monkey

狼与小羊羔: 一只猴子在一次百兽集会上跳舞，他的表演令全场大为欢喜，于是被选为国王。有一只狐狸嫉妒猴子取得的荣誉，她发现一个陷阱里有一片肉，于是她将猴子带到那儿，说她发现了一个藏宝洞，不过还没动过。她一直为猴子留着，好做他王国的无价之宝，还劝猴子要据为己有。猴子一时大意，便走了过去，结果掉进了陷阱。当猴子大骂狐狸故意引他掉进陷阱时，狐狸答道：“哦，猴子，就凭你这种头脑也配当百兽之王吗？”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A Monkey once danced in an assembly of the Beasts, and so pleased them all by his performance that they elected him their King.A Fox, envying him the honor, discovered a piece of meat lying in a trap, and leading the Monkey to the place where it was, said that she had found a store, but had not used it, she had kept it for him as treasure trove of his kingdom, and counseled him to lay hold of it.The Monkey approached carelessly and was caught in the trap; and on his accusing the Fox of purposely leading him into the snare, she replied, “O Monkey, and are you, with such a mind as yours, going to be King over the Beasts?”

狼与小羊羔: 马和它的主人
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Horse and His Rider

狼与小羊羔: 一个骑兵悉心照料着他的战马。只要战争持续，他就把战马视为一切危急情况下的助手，于是他用干草和谷物精心喂养着战马。但等战争结束了，他就只给它喂糟糠，还让它驮沉重的木材，强迫它做很多卑微的苦差事，不好好待它。然而，战争又爆发了，号角声声，唤他上阵。士兵为战马穿上军用马饰，自己也穿上了厚重的甲胄，然后纵身跃上马背。重压之下，马儿立刻就倒了下去，它再也承担不起这样的重量了。马对主人说：“现在你必须得徒步上战场了，因为你已经把我从一匹马变成了一头驴；你怎么能指望我一下子就从一头驴又变回一匹马呢？”
The Wolf and the Lamb: A horse soldier took the utmost pains with his charger.As long as the war lasted, he looked upon him as his fellow helper in all emergencies and fed him carefully with hay and corn.But when the war was over, he only allowed him chaff to eat and made him carry heavy loads of wood, subjecting him to much slavish drudgery and ill-treatment.War was again proclaimed, however, and when the trumpet summoned him to his standard, the Soldier put on his charger its military trappings, and mounted, being clad in his heavy coat of mail.The Horse fell down straightway under the weight, no longer equal to the burden, and said to his master, “You must now go to the war on foot, for you have transformed me from a Horse into an Ass; and how can you expect that I can again turn in a moment from an Ass to a Horse?”

狼与小羊羔: 胃和其他器官
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Belly and the Members

狼与小羊羔: 身体的其他器官共同刁难起胃来，抱怨道：“凭什么总是我们忙着帮助你满足需要，而你却什么也不做，在奢侈和自我放纵中独享其乐呢？”于是，器官们就下定决心拒绝再帮助胃。很快，整个身体都变得虚弱无力。手、脚、嘴和眼睛对他们的愚蠢做法感到后悔，可却为时已晚了。
The Wolf and the Lamb: The Members of the Body rebelled against the Belly, and said, “Why should we be perpetually engaged in administering to your wants, while you do nothing but take your rest, and enjoy yourself in luxury and self-indulgence?”The Members carried out their resolve and refused their assistance to the Belly.The whole Body quickly became debilitated, and the hands, feet, mouth, and eyes, when too late, repented of their folly.
